answers.body_markdown:
If I understand correctly you need two levels of `GROUP BY`. On the inner level you need number of distinct services per listing (blue house = 3, red house = 1, green = 1). On the outer level you calculate the average of 3, 1, 1:

    SELECT userid, AVG(service_type_count) AS avg_service_type_per_listing
    FROM (
        SELECT userid, reference, COUNT(DISTINCT service_type) AS service_type_count
        FROM orders
        GROUP BY userid, reference
    ) AS x
    GROUP BY userid

answers.body_markdown:
Your first case:<br>
you want to select a number if it has between 6 and 10 digits (both inclusive) and not more.
<br>your solution of `\d[0-9]{5,9}` has 2 problems:

- you're selecting all numbers with 5 to 9 digits 
- you do not check to see if the number has more than 10 digits

To make sure we select between 6 and 10 digits we can use `\d[0-9]{6,10}` and to check that there are no other digits before the ones we selected we use non-capturing groups `(?:^|\D)` to check for non-digit characters at the start of the selection.

your idea of using a positive look ahead for blanks and slashes works but is expensive (don't use them for single characters), you can instead just append `[ \/]` after your capture group to ensure your capture group is followed by either a space character or a slash

Thus you can use `(?:^|\D)(\d{6,10})[ \/]` for your first case.

Your second case has many restrictions and you seem to have just copied the first regex you could for a couple of them. 

Looking at the issues mentioned - 

- you don't need a negative look behind (again very expensive) you can use `[^abc]` before your capture group to ensure that it is not following the characters a, b or c (implementing this is up to you). 

- The same can be used after your capture group (to ensure that your number is not followed by the pound sign)

- This is where things get tricky, it would be much simpler if you had a general defined pattern (or patterns) for your international numbers,in this case you could build a regex to identify and ignore each set of the examples you have provided. (this is the best case I can think off, I hope someone could provide a more elegant solution)

You might be better off making a stricter definition of your initial number rather than trying to ignore a multitude of specific cases for international numbers

*PS - Stackoverflow is not a site to ask people to do your work for you, its to help clarify misunderstandings you may have with code that you have tried to implement or to better understand concepts related with development.

AND

12**3456789012**/2019   Slash

OK, i think this is \d[0-9]{5,9} plus positive look ahead, means \d[0-9]{5,9}(?= |\.|\/)

Up to 4 elements of a group of numbers whose first element starts with + or 00 followed by one, two or three digits, e.g.

Found the following statement during my research to achieve this but again have no idea where to place it into the string: \+[0-9]{1,} |0)[1-9]{2,} |0)[1-9]{3,}â€¦

Instead of blank, groups with the following characters shall also lead to a non match.

Up to 4 elements of a group of numbers whose first element starts with 0 followed by three or four digits, e.g.

Instead of blank, groups with the following characters shall also lead to a non match.

answers.body_markdown:
As pointed out in the comments, Tuple2 is just a class like any other. You can create your own like this:

```
case class MyTuple2[A, B](a: A, b: B)

val myTuples: List[MyTuple2[String, Int]] = List(MyTuple2("a", 1), MyTuple2("b", 2))
```

As for the syntax, you cannot override the syntax-sugar of normal tuples (afaik). There are certainly things you could do with implicits or macros to fake it, but I'd strongly encourage you not to do that as it's highly surprising to anyone else if something looks like a standard Tuple2, but doesn't behave like one.

answers.body_markdown:
By default, only the following PowerShell drives referencing registry locations are defined:

```powershell
PS> Get-PSDrive -PSProvider Registry

Name           Used (GB)     Free (GB) Provider      Root                                                                                                           CurrentLocation
----           ---------     --------- --------      ----                                                                                                           ---------------
HKCU                                   Registry      HKEY_CURRENT_USER                                                                                                             
HKLM                                   Registry      HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE                                                                                                            
```

That is, **only drives `HKCU:` and `HKLM:` exist by default**.

---

In order to access keys in the `HKEY_USERS` hive, you have two options:

* **Define a custom `HKU` PowerShell drive** using [`New-PSDrive`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.management/new-psdrive), as [theadzik](https://stackoverflow.com/users/5947738/theadzik) suggests in a comment, though that may not be worth it (in your case, you'll have to do that _inside the script block_ passed to `Invoke-Command`):

```
# Define drive HKU:
New-PSDrive -PSProvider Registry -Name HKU -Root HKEY_USERS
# Now you can use HKU:\... paths
```

* **Use provider prefix `registry::` with the native registry path**, which is **simpler for ad-hoc use**:

```
# E.g.
Get-ChildItem registry::HKEY_USERS\.DEFAULT
```

In the context of your command:

```powershell
Invoke-Command -ComputerName $inputPC -ScriptBlock { 
  Remove-Item 'registry::HKEY_USERS\S-1-5-25\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce'
}
answers.title: Cannot map HKU registry hive with powershell

Your problem statement is somewhat vague, as a clause can end using `",",":",";"`, but may not end the sentence.  To revise this problem, identify the punctuation you are looking for and set as a list.  

The following code identifies the starting position of all of your keywords. 
 Then, it locates the first instance of one of your identified punctuation marks that you deem as "end of clause/sentence" and returns it. 


    import re
    
    text = '''
        The exam is for testing your skills. The exam includes the following:
        1) Aptitude
        2)synonyms
        3)Reasoning'''
    
    targets =[m.start() for m in re.finditer('exam', text)]

    end_punct = ['!','.','?',':',';']

    for target in targets:
        subtext = text[target:]
        print(subtext)
        for char in subtext:
            if char in end_punct:
                print(char)
                break
    
Sample return:

    #Returns:
    .
    :

answers.body_markdown: The answer seems to be related to dimensionality associated to your models. Curse of dimensionality as it is also known. KD-tree has a very poor scaling when it comes to a dimension above 15/20 (kinda exponential) whereas brute Force seems to follow a more linear-like pattern. When run on GPUs, for higher dimensions, brute force can indeed be faster. Here another researcher found a similar problem: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/50551877/comparison-search-time-between-k-d-tree-and-brute-force
answers.title: Why does 'kd_tree' take more time than 'brute'?

answers.body_markdown:
In general, KD-Tree will be slower than brute force if `N < 2**k`, where `k` is the number of dimensions (in this case `8 * 8 = 64`) and `N` is the number of samples.  In this case `2**64 = 1.8E19 >> 1797`, so KDTree is far slower.

Basically, a KDTree does binary splits of the data along each dimension as a first step. If it has enough data to do that, it can guess the closest neighbors by the number of splits in common they have.  If `N < 2**k`, it runs out of data before it runs out of dimensions to split.  It then has no distance information about the other dimensions.  With no good guess, it still has to brute force the rest of the dimensions, making the KDTree unnecessary overhead.

A more in-depth discussion of the issues and possible solutions can be found [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/5751114/nearest-neighbors-in-high-dimensional-data).  For this application, the third answer suggesting using PCA first to reduce your dimensionality is probably your best bet.
answers.title: Why does 'kd_tree' take more time than 'brute'?

answers.body_markdown:
If you don't control the consuming application and it expects to be reading from the file system, there may be a way of doing this but it's a fair bit of work.

Recent releases of Windows 10 have included the [Windows Projected File System][1]. Windows takes care of all of the file system interception and you just have to be able to answer questions like ["what files are meant to be in this directory?"][2] and the like. I believe it's now used for OneDrive and that's one of the intended uses - where the actual files may normally reside in cloud storage rather than locally.

You do have to make file content available [as Windows demands it][3]. The one thing to say though is that it's not an easy job direct from C#. If you're going to try binding to this API, it really helps if you understand a bit of C or C++ too.

Earlier this year I was looking to create a managed binding to this API to make consumption easier from .NET languages. It's not, however, currently in a releasable state. But the basics worked and proves that this is a viable approach.

Once .NET Core 3 is fully released I'll probably dust this off again and make it work well, but for now it's a [WIP][4]


  [1]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/projfs/projected-file-system
  [2]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/projfs/enumerating-files-and-directories
  [3]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/projfs/providing-file-data
  [4]: https://github.com/Damien-The-Unbeliever/ProjectedFileSystem

I've been using a STM32H753I-EVAL2 board for several months now.

Last week I was suddenly not able to connect to the board anymore (tried with several tools: GDB, STM32cubeProgrammer, always same message like "STLink error"). I of course checked the driver was correctly installed and was the right one, reinstalled it, changed USB cable and ports. Also tried to connect to a Nucleo which was fine. 

I randomly tried to change the power supply of the board from PSU (ie. powering through external power supply) to STLink (powering through USB) and it solved the issue. I was happy as I thought it was just a hardware issue like a conflict between both power supplies.

But today the board was not connecting anymore again. So I switched back the alim to PSU and it worked !

Did someone experience the same issue ? Or does it trigger something for someone ?

answers.body_markdown:
There is a misconception on port mapping: you're passing all your traffic from host port 3306 to container port 3306, but that's not bidirectional.

To manage your situation, if you're on Linux (it does not works in Windows and Mac) you can add in your docker-compose.yml this configuration, allowing the container to use host services.

>     network_mode: "host"

Otherwise you could setup your local MySql to accept connection from external IPs and point container database to your IP address. 

Please note that this solution would work fine only in local development machine, I strongly suggest to avoid this in any production environment.
answers.title: Docker compose spring boot couldn't connect to mysql db

answers.body_markdown:
When running a compose "stack", docker uses its own DNS mechanism.

This means that if you perform a DNS query inside of the `account_app` container for the hostname `mysql`, the query would return the IP address of the container named `mysql` (possibly prefixed with the stack name)

**In short**: Configure your Spring application to connect to a mysql db not on localhost but on `mysql` and you are good to go.

There probably are some environmental variables which you could set to configure this.
answers.title: Docker compose spring boot couldn't connect to mysql db

answers.body_markdown:
I think you use "localhost" as mysql server hostname, 

    jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306

try changing it to 

    jdbc:mysql://host.docker.internal:3306

You cannot localhost inside a docker container.
Best way to do this is by passing jdbc url as a environment variable.

    SPRING_DATASOURCE_URL=jdbc:mysql://host.docker.internal:3306/code_master

Please check the last 5 lines of this sh file, https://github.com/keaz/code_master/blob/develop/build_docker.sh

answers.body_markdown:
Your steps from 1 to 7 almost no thing do with the error.

> service example-service (instance i-016b0a460d9974567) (port 1047) is
> unhealthy in target-group example-service due to (reason Request timed
> out)

The error is very clear, you ECS service is not reachable to Load balancer health check.

 **Target Group Unhealthy**


When this is the case, go straight and check the container SG, Port, application status or health status code.


Possible reason

 - There might be the case, there is no route  `Path  /healthcheck` in the backend service
 - The status code from `/healthcheck` is not `200`
 - Might be the case that target port is invalid, configure it correctly, if an application running on port 8080 or 3000 it should be `3000` or `8080`
 - The security group is not allowing traffic on the target group
 - Application is not running in the container
 

These are the possible reason when there is a timeout from health check.

This causes our dependent service to start experiencing 504 gateway timeout which impacts them in big way.


1. Upgraded Docker storage driver from devicemapper to overlay2

2. We increased the resources for all ECS instances including CPU, RAM and EBS storage as we saw in few containers.

3. We increase health check grace period for the service from 0 to 240secs

answers.body_markdown:
Do a fetch of the remtoe changes in TortoiseGit using "Git Fetch".

Then go to the "Log" and activate "Show all branches" (or click on the upper left blue label to select the branches you want to see). Then you can see your local branch and the remotely pushed commits.
answers.title: How do I view the commits added to the branch I'm tracking?

answers.body_markdown:
Assuming you are currently on the Develop branch, in the TortoiseGit log view click the branch name 'develop' in the top left.

The 'Browse References' dialog will open, in the ref tree on the left of that dialog select the node refs/remotes/origin/develop and click Ok to close the dialog.

The log will now update to show the origin/develop branch, however since your local develop branch is tracking this remote branch your develop branch is simply a tag pointing to one of the commits in this remote branch, which you will see as the bolded log entry with the 'develop' branch tag, followed by all the subsequent commits to the origin/develop branch right up to the origin/develop branch tag at the top.

After browsing the subsequent commits (and assuming you have no uncommitted changes) you can update your tracking branch with the latest remote commits by right clicking the topmost commit which will have the branch tags origin/head,origin/develop and selecting 'merge to develop' which will perform a fast forward merge of the outstanding commits into your local 'develop' branch (in effect just moving the local 'develop' branch tag to the same changeset as the origin/develop branch).

answers.body_markdown:
There are three main steps required:

 1. Lambda must return the image as base64 encoded string: `return image.toString('base64')`
 2. In API Gateway > Method Execution > Integration Request > Mapping Templates - add `Content-Type: image/png`
 3. In API Settings enable Binary Media Types and set it as `image/png`

Deploy API and in POSTMAN call the endpoint URL with headers: `Accept: image/png` and `Content-Type: image/png`.

That's it. This will return the image correctly as image!

If anyone needs more details, I've created a full tutorial that goes through each step:
https://medium.com/@iaforek/how-to-configure-binary-support-in-api-gateway-the-easy-and-working-way-ac2d68face36

What's important, you **don't** need to use `CONVERT_TO_BINARY` passthrough as other blog posts suggest.

items.body_markdown:
# Introduction

TLDR: https://codesandbox.io/s/elated-jennings-6budz. Why does red not do the same as blue **in chrome**? Is this a bug?

Im **useing chrome** version: 76.0.3809.132. In firefox everything works as expected.

# Question

Im using the waapi to implement an animation relying on a custom timeline (for example the scroll position as timeline). The concept goes as follows:

The waapi allowes you to start an animation midway through by setting the `iterationStart` option somewhere between 0 and 1 (assuming the animation has just one iteration). When the animation is then immediately paused we get the requested frame. As the next imput gets in, we override the last frame.

So when we get the input of say 0.5 we'd use the following code:

```
//           test keyframes
elem.animate({marginLeft: ["0px", "600px"]}, {
  duration: 100, 
  easing: "linear",
  fill: "both", 
  iterations: 1, 
  iterationStart: 0.5 // input
}).pause()
```

This works perfectly, even with as we set such a frame every 1/60 sec. The problem however arises as we want to ease the aniamtion (e.g. `easing: "ease"` not `linear`). This introduces wierd gliches where the animation jumps around at **the same progress every time** (progress = iterationSatrt / input). The first jump for example is at `0.148` using `ease` as easing function. Can someone explain this behaviour? Is this a bug? 

I have come across the follwing correlation. `0.148 * 2` eased with the `ease` function is just over `0.5`. To calculate this I use the `bezier-easing` library. Here the example: https://runkit.com/embed/1wetjf7jjb2s. I dont know if this is at all relevant but I thought Id share my findings.

Here the codesandbox link showing the problem: https://codesandbox.io/s/elated-jennings-6budz. Please note to not let it run too long at a time without reloading. 

The blue div uses a fix to show the expected result. For this I kept `easeing: "linear"` but customly eased each input with the `bezier-easing` library as shown above (and in the code).

answers.body_markdown:
Consensus in Corda happens at two levels:

 - Validity Consensus 
 - Uniqueness Consensus

https://docs.corda.net/key-concepts-consensus.html

**Validity Consensus** involves running the contract by each of the parties involved in the transaction, and providing an agreement on the outcome of the transaction in the form for signature.

**Uniqueness Consensus**, on the other hand, is taken care of by the notary, where it checks for double-spending.

So in your example notary would just check if the input used in the transaction involving Alice paying $20 to Bob, the notary (non-validating) cannot check for the validity part of the consensus, all it checks is whether the input used in the transaction has already been spent or not.

The validity part i.e. where the $20 payment is actually valid, has to be checked at the contract level, by the parties. They need to check that the amount of cash in the input state should be equal to the amount of cash in the output state of the transaction.

This, however, would require Bob to verify the entire transaction chain, which is also the case with any transaction in Corda, this is required as Bob was unaware of the state in question as he never used to have to state to validate that it was indeed valid.

This could be a privacy breach, hence Charlie could use a confidential identity which transacting which would hide his identity in the transaction chain, hence Bob would only know that there was a transaction in which Alice received $10 from an anonymous entity and Charlie's identity would not be revealed.

In future versions of Corda, nodes would likely only exchange transaction chains in SGX-encrypted form. These transaction chains will then be verified inside an SGX enclave on the node. This will prevent nodes from seeing the contents of the transactions they are verifying (see the blogpost here: https://www.corda.net/2017/06/corda-sgx-privacy-update/). This may even go so far as to only allow nodes to see certain parts of the transactions they are signing.

Hope this answers your question.
answers.title: R3 Corda: How is the validity of a transaction input checked with non-validating notaries without revealing the history of the transaction?

Output:

answers.body_markdown:
If nothing exists it's because it's not "really" possible. 

1st, it's useful to ask ["When Pubsub generate double values?"](https://cloud.google.com/pubsub/docs/subscriber#at-least-once-delivery). Only when a message is delivered and the acknowledge is not received (or not emit in the expected time frame, 10s by default), or a no HTTP 200 is received in push mode.

2nd: What is Beam? Beam is a pipeline engine. You can plug your PubSub to it and 
 your pipeline will read message and deduplicate them. Be careful this deduplication is performed in a windows of 10 to 20 minutes by Beam.

3rd: What mean "ordered"? Look at the ID of your message. The value is a timestamp, in microsecond (that's why PubSub can ingest up to 1M of message per second). Ordered the message mean having a message for sequential ID, else put in a buffer and wait for fill in the gaps. Of course, gaps will never be filled in...

Go back to Beam. Beam has the capability to define [windows of observation](https://beam.apache.org/documentation/programming-guide/#windowing). By the way, you can define, for example, sliding windows of 5 minutes, each windows starting every minute. When a window is closed, a PCollection of messages is triggered and it processed into your pipeline. On this finite collection, you can ordered your message. 

With the same principle, you can remove depublicates manually in this collection.

Last info, PubSub is a backbone of Google service. It evolves, slowly because it's critical. But, maybe your requirement will be release a day!

answers.body_markdown:
The simplest (and also usually taken approach) is to connect the vertices of the polygon in a linkedlist and arrange them such that the successors are arranged in counter-clockwise order around the area of the polygon. This way, the area of the polygon is always to the right of any edge.

[![enter image description here][1]][1]

Even if parts of the above square were covered up, you'd still be able to determine where the inside of the polygon lies. The sorting itself can be done in `O(n)`, if points aren't already in the appropriate order (quite likely).

  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/pI7Be.png
answers.title: Can I determine, using only a subset of polygon points, where the interior of the polygon lies?

answers.body_markdown:
what you need is dissect your polygons into sections like this:

 [![sections][1]][1]

1. **chose some interior point `C` (Aqua center)**

 this point must be inside your polygon and its best if it is placed at the center of your polygon. You can obtain it as a center of BBOX, or center of a diagonal (line between any 2 points of polygon circumference far enough between each other like half of points) or intersection of 2 diagonals or as a average of all points or even randomly or however you want ...

 then just check if it lies inside polygon. This however must be done with slow approach (using all polygon points). Luckily this point is needed to compute just once (on creation/load/init of polygon).

 in case of wrong center just use different points to generate it or move it slightly until its inside.

2. **divide your polygon into sections**

 using diagonal lines (gray lines) between selected center and any polygon point. Select points so the sections have roughly the same number of points and the diagonal itself **must not intersect any polygon edge**. So if you got `m` points and want `n` sections use every `m-th` point as diagonal... and if it intersects use nearby point instead until it is correct.
 
 The section should be done also just once per polygon.

3. **faster inside**

 Now to detect if any point (Magenta) is inside first check which section it is by doing **CW/CCW** check between all diagonals or using `atan2` (in which case each diagonal angle can be precomputed once to speed up the process) finding two diagonals that envelope point in question:

 [![section][2]][2]

 so find diagonal which is CW to the point and has minimal angle ... and also another one that is CCW. If "center" point is `C` and tested point is `P` and diagonal points are `D(i)` then

        angle = acos(dot(P-C,D(i)-C)/(|P-C|*|D(i)-C|))

 and z coordinate of `cross(P-C,D(i)-C)` will tell you if the diagonal/angle is CW or CCW. I think you can ignore the `acos` as the nonlinear result without it should be still monotonic so `min,max` will be still correct.

 This will tell you in which section the point is so now do polygon inside check but use just the section points and used diagonals instead of whole polygon.

 Now when you have your 2 closest diagonals CW `D(i)` and CCW `D(j)` then just test polygon constructed from `C` and all points between `D(i)` and `D(j)`.

 [![point inside section][3]][3]

 As you can see the more sections you have the less points you need for checking (but more diagonals) ...

 

**PS** this note is for Paul

Algorithm using **CW/CCW**-ness works only for convex polygons on concave ones there are false negatives like in this image:

 [![error][4]][4]


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/ekZmW.png
  [2]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/xkj3z.png
  [3]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/sQCEH.png
  [4]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/qaTBu.png
answers.title: Can I determine, using only a subset of polygon points, where the interior of the polygon lies?

answers.body_markdown:
The usual approach would be to project a line horizontally left from your given point and find the nearest edge that that line intersects. The direction of that edge tells you whether the point is inside or outside the polygon (with a path direction imposed as per Paul's suggestion). If no edge is encountered, you are, of course, outside.

To achieve this, you need each cell of your binary tree to reference every edge that *passes through* the cell, *even if its vertices are outside the cell*. You may sometimes need to traverse through multiple cells to find the nearest intersecting edge.

To illustrate:

[![enter image description here][1]][1]

Within the cell that contains our point of interest (see the right-hand enlargement above), we project a line out from the point to the left. It meets no edges before it hits the cell boundary. So we must traverse into the next cell over, and continue our line. It hits an edge whose y-direction is positive; thus we conclude the point is *outside* the polygon.

Observe that a cell can hold information for vertices that fall outside the cell boundaries, so that every edge that passes across the cell is referenced.

This approach works for polygons of any complexity *as long as they do not self-intersect*, as well as shapes with multiple (unconnected) contours.

**Dealing with self-intersecting polygons:**

If you expect to encounter self-intersecting polygons, you can no longer tell if you are inside or outside by examining just the *nearest* edge. You must instead use the [non-zero winding rule][2] or the [even odd rule][3], which require counting *all* edges to the left of your point.

In this case, you probably shouldn't bother making x-wise splits in your binary tree: instead let each cell cover the entire width of the polygon, and only split in the y-axis. There is little point creating multiple cells across the x-axis when on average you'll have to traverse through half of them anyway. This makes the algorithm simpler, as you only need to look at one cell to find all edges to the left of your point.

But you can go a step further. As you are only splitting in one axis, you can abandon your standard binary tree and instead use an [interval tree][4] for best efficiency. The simplest variety is an *augmented* interval tree.

**An edge case (excuse the pun) to be careful of when coding this up:**

If your projected line passes directly through a vertex: this vertex is part of *two* edges, so which does the line hit first? It can make a big difference. To simplify this situation you should *only* consider an edge to be intersected if the y-position of the projected line is *strictly less than* the y position of the highest of the edge's two vertices.

Below are illustrated three points, whose projected lines pass through the lowest vertex, the mid-point and the highest vertex of an edge ('highest' meaning largest y-value; edge direction is unimportant here). The first two lines intersect the edge; the third doesn't.

[![enter image description here][5]][5]

As a result, perfectly horizontal edges are always ignored, and you can if you wish skip these when populating your binary tree (or interval tree).

If using an interval tree, you can deal with this edge case directly in the tree's search routine.


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/M0VMw.png
  [2]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonzero-rule
  [3]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Even%E2%80%93odd_rule
  [4]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interval_tree
  [5]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/32Igk.png

answers.body_markdown:
I think there are different policies, in Firefox you are able to request the stylesheet as Firefox uses CORS (https://www.w3.org/wiki/CORS#xml-stylesheet_processing_instruction_.28XMLSS.29) on `xml-stylesheet` based requests while Chrome does not apply CORS on such requests, nor does Safari/Webkit (https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=110880).

So the latter block the attempt, the former only fulfills it as it uses CORS for the request and your app on http://documents.server/ is set up to allow requests to anyone by answering with `access-control-allow-origin: *`. If http://documents.server/ would not do that then the cross origin loading would fail even in Firefox.
answers.title: XML in a frame does not load XSLT - whose problem is this, Chrome, Firefox or mine?

items.body_markdown:
I have a very basic ASP.NET MVC 5 application, hosted on an intranet server, where one of the pages has an `iframe` to display a document:

```html
<div class="document-view-container">
    ...
    <iframe class="document-frame" src="@Url.Action("GetDocumentImage", "Imaging", ...)" ></iframe>   
    ...
</div>
```

The returned document is sometimes a PDF served as `application/pdf`, sometimes a piece of text served as `text/plain`, and sometimes an XML served as `text/xml`.

The `GetDocumentImage` method retrieves the document contents from a database and returns it using [`File`][2]:

```cs
return File(doc.document.ToArray(), doc.mime_type);
```

When the document happens to be an XML, it often includes a reference to a stylesheet with which it should be viewed:

```xml
<?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" href="//server.local/folder/content/grn.xslt"?>
<document>
   ...
</document>
```

Sometimes that stylesheet comes from the same subdomain as what the `@Url.Action()` returns (i.e. same origin with the `iframe`), but sometimes it does not.

When it does not, the stylesheet is successfully loaded and used in Firefox, but Chrome refuses to load the stylesheet and displays an error in console,

> Unsafe attempt to load URL `http://server.local/folder/content/grn.xslt` from frame with URL `http://documents.server/imaging/GetDocumentImage/52855`. Domains, protocols and ports must match.

This is a known problem, but my understanding was that it only applies to local files, not to files served from a server, and one of the solutions is specifically to [host the files on a server][1]. Besides, it works in Firefox.

What is the source of this problem?

- Is it Chrome, that treats the XML in an `iframe` as a local file and therefore incorrectly prevents it from requesting a stylesheet from the server?
- Is it Firefox, that has a security issue where it would allow an XML file from an `iframe` request a stylesheet when it should be prohibited?
- Is it me, who is not serving the XML from the server properly enough making Chrome mistake it for a local file?

What is the proper way to fix it?

[1]: https://stackoverflow.com/a/6251757/11683
[2]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.web.mvc.controller.file?view=aspnet-mvc-5.2#System_Web_Mvc_Controller_File_System_Byte___System_String_

answers.body_markdown:
When you write

    Write-host â€œhelloâ€

You actually get :

  

    'hello' | Out-Default | Out-Host

 
PowerShell will apply the default formatting (which can be altered by configuration files on the host) to Out-default and the again to out-host (display in our case) .
Even worst, the formatting rules are different among versions and for desktop and server PowerShell.

try with `write-output` to see if you get different formatting.
